docs.lead_paragraph: If there is one thing that separates the self-employed from those employed by others, it is their preoccupation with health insurance.

headline.main: Finding Health Insurance if You Are Self-Employed
headline.print_headline: The Hunt for Health Insurance For Those Who Are Self-Employed

docs.snippet: If there is one thing that separates the self-employed from those employed by others, it is their preoccupation with health insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the regulars at Shifting Careers know, we've been doing a lot of talking about health insurance for the self-employed since my initial post, Health Insurance for the Self-Employed, and a follow-up post, The Minefield of Health Insurance, a few weeks later. While it is shameful that adequate and affordable health insurance is so difficult to find that it affects people's career choices, I did find one bright light in researching this subject. People are willing to share information in a way that genuinely helps others, that is until the government or private industry steps up with some better solutions.

headline.main: Let's Talk About Health Insurance. And Talk, and Talk.

docs.lead_paragraph: Following is a second set of answers from James R. Knickman, the president and chief executive of the New York State Health Foundation, who is taking questions from readers through March 29 on a range of issues from universal health care and Medicaid to the prevalence in New York of problems like obesity, diabetes, smoking and substance abuse. Readers are invited to submit additional questions using the comment form below.

headline.main: Answers About Health in New York, Part 2

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students investigate the relationships between health care, socioeconomic class, racial background and life expectancy in America and create public awareness campaigns designed to inform people about specific health risks that are known to lower life expectancy.
